questions.question: A 35 y/o woman presents with an incidental liver mass found on ultrasound. Further imaging with CT and MRI is performed, revealing a well-defined mass with a central scar which is hyperintense on T2w MRI. The lesion shows hot spot on sulphur colloid scan. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.explanation: with a central stellate scar, which can sometimes contain calcifications. The presence of these features on imaging is highly suggestive of FNH. Radiological Comparison of Focal Nodular Hyperplasia and Fibrolamellar Carcinoma: Feature FNH FLC Ultrasound It is difficult to detect as it has similar reflectivity to the liver. Solid, hyperechoic lesions, central scar and calcification may be seen CT Well-defined lobulated mass, isoattenuating to liver parenchyma; marked homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase with a central low-attenuation scar, mass effect visible. (Option C) Well-defined mass, often hyperattenuating; may enhance the arterial phase (Option D ruled out) MRI Isointense on T1, hyperintense on T2; central scar hypointense on T1 Hyperintense on T1 if fat-containing, significant enhancement on arterial phase. Key Differentiator Central stellate scar: Enhances on CT/MRI; no calcification Scar+ , calcification more common Hepatic adenoma (Option A) : This is usually a hypervascular lesion without a central scar or calcifications. Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option B) : Although it can present with heterogeneity and arterial phase enhancement, a central scar with calcifications is not characteristic.

questions.question: Which of the following is the hallmark radiological feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) on MRCP?

options.B: Beaded appearance due to alternating strictures and dilations
options.C: A single long stricture in the common bile duct
options.D: Multiple large masses in the liver

questions.explanation: MRCP. The alternating areas of narrowing and dilation give the bile ducts a characteristic "beaded" or string-of-pearls appearance. This pattern reflects the chronic, patchy inflammation and fibrosis that affects both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts in PSC, making it a key diagnostic feature for this condition. There is also obliteration of the peripheral portions of the ducts - giving it the “pruned tree” appearance. MRCP showing a beaded appearance of dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in PSC ERCP A) Beaded appearance, B) Pruned tree appearance, C) Band-like strictures Diffuse dilation of bile ducts (Option A): PSC does not cause uniform dilation throughout the bile ducts. Instead, the disease leads to segmental areas of narrowing (strictures) and dilations, which result from progressive inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. A single long stricture in the common bile duct (Option C): A single long stricture would be more indicative of cholangiocarcinoma or a malignant obstruction, rather than PSC. Multiple large masses in the liver (Option D): The presence of large masses in the liver would suggest a different pathology, such as metastatic liver disease or advanced hepatocellular carcinoma, rather than PSC.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis presents with abdominal discomfort. Ultrasound shows a heterogeneous liver mass with a "nodule-in-nodule" appearance. CT reveals a hypervascular lesion with mosaic enhancement and washout on delayed phases. MRI demonstrates decreased T1 and increased T2 signal intensities with late arterial enhancement. Based on the imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65 y/o diabetic male presents with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and signs of sepsis. A USG reveals highly echogenic reflectors with dirty shadowing and ring-down artefacts in the gallbladder. Subsequent CT imaging demonstrates gas within the gallbladder wall and pneumoperitoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: findings of emphysematous cholecystitis, especially in a diabetic patient with high sepsis risk. Emphysematous Cholecystitis Definition : A rare, severe form of acute cholecystitis with gallbladder wall necrosis causing gas formation within the lumen or wall; surgical emergency due to high risk of gangrene and perforation. Radiographic Diagnosis : Air detected in the gallbladder wall or bile ducts without any abnormal communication to the GI tract. Ultrasound Features : Highly echogenic reflectors with low-level posterior shadowing and reverberation artefact (dirty shadowing and ring-down artefact). Champagne Sign : Pathognomonic sign showing non-shadowing echogenic foci rising from the dependent portion of the gallbladder, resembling bubbles in champagne. CT Imaging : The most sensitive and specific modality for detecting gas within the gallbladder wall or lumen. Pneumoperitoneum on CT suggests gallbladder perforation. Chronic cholecystitis (Option A) and Acute calculous Cholecystitis (Option B) are less likely as they do not usually feature gas in the gallbladder wall or pneumoperitoneum. Gallbladder Adenocarcinoma (Option D) is unlikely since gallbladder adenocarcinoma rarely presents with intramural gas or signs of acute infection.

questions.question: A 55 y/o perimenopausal woman presents with vague abdominal pain. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a large, multilocular cystic lesion in the tail of the pancreas with thick septations and peripheral calcifications. Lab results show elevated CEA levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: pancreatic tail with malignant potential, common in perimenopausal women. Cystic Pancreatic Lesions Pseudocysts • Fluid contains high amylase • Post-inflammatory, non-neoplastic. Serous Cystic Neoplasm (SCN) • Common Site: Head of the pancreas. • Imaging Features : Multiple small cysts, sometimes with central scar calcification.Honeycomb pattern, possible stellate scar. • Benign : Rarely malignant. • Common in : Older women in their 6-s-70s - hence called grandmother tumour. Mucinous Cystic Neoplasm (MCN) • Common Site: Tail of the pancreas. • Imaging Features : Large, multilocular, thick septations, peripheral calcifications, and sometimes solid components. • Risk : Malignant transformation • Common in : Perimenopausal women (40-60 years-Mother tumour.) Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm (IPMN) • Types : Main duct, branch duct, mixed. • Common Site: Ductal origin—main duct or branch duct. • Risk : Higher malignancy risk in main duct type. • Main duct IPMNs : Show cystic dilatation of the main duct, enhancing mural nodules , and viscid mucus causing obstruction. • Protruding ampulla of Vater-Fish mouth appearance Solid Pseudopapillary Tumor (SPT) : • Imaging Features : Large, encapsulated, solid and cystic mass, often with haemorrhage &necrosis. • Demographics : Young women (Daughter tumour), particularly in Asian and African-American populations. Pseudocysts (Option A) are typically the result of pancreatitis and do not have thick septations, calcifications, or elevated CEA levels. They also lack cystic neoplasm characteristics like a multilocular appearance and are not associated with elevated tumour markers like CEA. Serous Cystic Neoplasm (Option C) : SCNs tend to have a microcystic appearance (many small cysts) and are usually benign, with no elevated CEA levels. They are also more commonly located in the head of the pancreas rather than the tail. Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm (IPMN) (Option D): IPMNs are usually connected to the pancreatic duct and are more commonly found in the head of the pancreas. While they may also present with elevated CEA, they are often associated with dilation of the pancreatic duct (Fish mouth appearance), which is not mentioned in this case.

questions.question: A 60 y/o man presents with recurrent abdominal pain and jaundice. A CT abdomen reveals a "sausage-shaped" pancreas and long segmental pancreatic duct strictures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: along with long segmental ductal strictures. The pancreas may appear diffusely enlarged, and ductal strictures without significant calcification or atrophy help differentiate this from chronic pancreatitis. Imaging Modality Chronic pancreatitis Autoimmune Pancreatitis CT scan • Calcifications within the pancreas. • Pancreatic atrophy with dilated ductal system. • Irregularities or strictures of the pancreatic duct. • Diffuse pancreatic enlargement (" sausage-shaped " appearance). • Homogeneous delayed enhancement of the pancreas. • Capsule-like rim of low density, suggesting peripancreatic inflammation or fibrosis. • Ductal narrowing or strictures MRCP • Characteristic " chain of lakes " appearance due to alternating strictures and dilatation of the pancreatic duct. Chronic pancreatitis (Option A) typically shows ductal dilations and calcifications, but the "sausage-shaped" pancreas is more specific for autoimmune pancreatitis. Necrotising pancreatitis (Option C) is usually associated with severe acute inflammation, necrosis, and fluid collections, not strictures. Pancreatic pseudocyst (Option D) refers to a fluid collection following pancreatitis but does not cause "sausage-shaped" pancreatic enlargement or strictures.

questions.question: A 45 y/o woman with a history of acute pancreatitis presents with persistent abdominal pain and weight loss. A CT scan performed 5 weeks after her initial episode shows a thick-walled fluid collection containing gas bubbles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: walled-off necrosis. (Option B) Feature Pseudocyst (Option A) Walled-off Necrosis (Option B) Definition Encapsulated fluid collection that develops more than 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis. Encapsulated collection of necrotic material , which develops after 4 weeks in necrotising pancreatitis Gas Presence No gas (Option A ruled out) Gas bubbles may indicate infection Location Peripancreatic space (may extend to mediastinum) Pancreatic and/or peripancreatic tissues Imaging findings Homogeneous low-attenuation fluid with capsule CT showing pseudocyst Thick-walled collection may show gas on CT CT Showing “walled off necrosis” Resolution Most resolve spontaneously. If more than 5 cm or recurrent, cystogastrostomy is done Often requires drainage or necrosectomy if infected Abscess (Option C): While an abscess may also contain gas, it is generally associated with infection and may not specifically relate to pancreatitis. questions.question: A 52 y/o man diagnosed with necrotizing pancreatitis presents with worsening abdominal pain. A CT scan on day 3 of his illness is performed. What is the most likely imaging finding seen on day 3 in this patient?

options.C: Non-enhancing areas in the pancreatic body and tail

questions.explanation: tissue necrosis. Features of Acute Pancreatitis Interstitial edematous pancreatitis: Swollen pancreas with intact microcirculation, showing homogeneous contrast enhancement, often with mild peripancreatic fat stranding and fluid. Necrotizing pancreatitis: Disruption of microcirculation leads to nonenhancement of necrotic pancreatic tissue, with time-dependent pancreatic and peripancreatic inflammatory changes. Imaging Findings in Acute Pancreatitis Bulky Pancreas • Enlarged pancreas with heterogeneous enhancement. • Mild thickening of pancreatic tissue. • Indicative of oedema in acute interstitial edematous pancreatitis. CECT revealing bulky pancreas Renal halo sign: • The "renal halo" sign presents as a high-density outline around the kidney indicating the inflammatory process in acute pancreatitis extending toward the left pancreatic tail and left pararenal space CECT revealing Renal halo sign CT Findings Day 1: • Normally enhancing pancreas Day 3: • Significant necrosis observed. • The greater part of the pancreatic body and tail shows no enhancement. Post 2 weeks: • Gas bubbles in the peripancreatic collection are consistent with an infected acute necrotic collection. Features of chronic pancreatitis Parenchymal calcifications Ductal dilatation Parenchymal atrophy due to fibrosis and chronic damage. Cystic lesions Bulky pancreas with mild thickening (Option A) : This finding is characteristic of interstitial edematous pancreatitis , not necrotizing pancreatitis. Parenchymal calcifications (Option B) indicate chronic changes and are not typically seen in acute necrotizing pancreatitis. Homogeneous enhancement of the pancreas (Option D) : This finding suggests intact microcirculation and is typical of early interstitial edematous pancreatitis , not necrotizing pancreatitis.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to his back, ongoing for four days. Serum lipase is elevated. A contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals over 30% pancreatic necrosis, multiple peripancreatic fluid collections, and bilateral pleural effusions. Based on the Modified CT Severity Index (MCTSI) for acute pancreatitis, how would you grade this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation: pancreatitis based on imaging findings. The patient has: Pancreatic/peripancreatic fluid collections and fat necrosis (4 points) Pancreatic necrosis (>30%) (4 points) Extrapancreatic complications (bilateral pleural effusions) (2 points) Total points: 10 , which classifies the condition as severe according to MCTSI (8-10 points). Modified CT Severity Index for Acute Pancreatitis Pancreatic inflammation Points Normal Pancreas 0 Intrinsic pancreatic abnormalities with/without inflammatory changes in peripancreatic fat 2 Pancreatic or peripancreatic fluid collection or peripancreatic fat necrosis. 4 Pancreatic necrosis:- None 0 ≤ 30% 2 >30% 4 Extrapancreatic complications (pleural effusion, ascites, vascular complications, GI tract involvement) 2 Total 0-2 Points = Mild 4-6 = Moderate 8-10 = Severe Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, 7th Edition, Page 684

questions.question: A 50 y/o man presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for the past two days. His serum lipase is elevated to five times the normal limit. An abdominal X-ray shows a dilated loop of small intestine near the pancreas. Which of the following is the most likely imaging sign observed on the X-ray in this patient?
questions.explanation: levels strongly suggests acute pancreatitis . Sentinel loop sign is a classic X-ray finding in acute pancreatitis, showing a dilated loop of the small intestine near the pancreas due to localized ileus caused by the inflammation.

questions.question: Which investigation is most sensitive for detecting bile leakage but does not provide information about the exact location of the leak?
questions.explanation: works by injecting a radioactive tracer that travels through the biliary system, highlighting any bile leakage. However, it cannot precisely identify the origin of the leak, making it less useful for surgical planning or pinpointing the exact location. HIDA scan: Most sensitive for bile leak (gold standard is ERCP) Most accurate for acute cholecystitis (IOC- USG) Best investigation to rule out EHBA (gold standard - PTC) CECT (Option B): CECT is the initial imaging study used in patients with suspected postoperative complications. It is useful for identifying localized fluid collections such as bilomas (encapsulated bile) or abscesses. While it can indicate the presence of fluid that might suggest a bile leak, it is less sensitive than HIDA for confirming the leak itself and may miss smaller leaks. MRI with Hepatobiliary Contrast (Option C): MRI with hepatobiliary-specific contrast agents, like gadoxetate disodium, effectively visualises the anatomy of the biliary system and can identify the exact location of a leak by showing contrast extravasation, but it is not sensitive in detecting leaks as compared to HIDA scan. Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography (Option D): PTC is a specialized imaging technique where a contrast dye is injected directly into the bile ducts through a needle inserted into the liver. While it can provide details of the biliary anatomy, it is not typically the first choice for detecting leaks and is used more often when ductal injury is suspected.

questions.question: A 2-month-old infant presents with persistent jaundice and pale stools. An ultrasound reveals no biliary dilation but shows the "triangular cord sign." Which condition is most likely suggested by this finding?
questions.explanation: a fibrotic remnant of the bile ducts near the porta hepatis. Other ultrasound findings include an absent/abnormal gallbladder and a wide hepatic artery. Biliary atresia also presents with persistent jaundice and pale stools in infancy, which further supports this diagnosis. Triangular cord sign on USG Other Investigations: HIDA Scan: Lack of tracer in the duodenum after 24 hours suggests biliary atresia. Radioisotope Studies: Highly sensitive to biliary atresia but poor specificity due to other conditions affecting bile excretion (e.g., infections, metabolic diseases). Preoperative percutaneous transhepatic cholecysto-cholangiography combined with liver biopsy has 100% sensitivity Definitive diagnosis: Intraoperative cholangiography Choledochal Cyst (Option A): They are characterized by abnormal dilation of the bile ducts, which is absent in this case. Ultrasound in choledochal cysts typically shows prominent bile ducts and potential cystic formations, thus making it an unlikely diagnosis. Neonatal Hepatitis (Option C): Although neonatal hepatitis can cause jaundice in infants, it does not present with the triangular cord sign. Caroli’s Disease (Option D): This is a rare condition associated with segmental dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts, leading to bile duct cyst formation. The absence of bile duct dilation in this case makes Caroli’s disease an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about imaging modalities used in the liver is FALSE?

options.A: USG is the first-line investigation for hepatic disorders.
options.B: T1-weighted images show a normal liver as hypointense compared to the spleen and kidney.
options.C: CT allows multiphasic examinations, including arterial, portal, and delayed phases.
options.D: Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is primarily reserved for therapeutic purposes.

questions.explanation: and kidney. Correct Answer: B) T1-weighted images show a normal liver as hypointense compared to the spleen and kidney. Explanation: Normal liver parenchyma appears hyperintense on T1-weighted images compared to the spleen, kidney, and pancreas. Imaging Techniques of Liver Ultrasonography • First-line investigation for hepatic disorders. (Option A ruled out) • Cost-effective and useful for repeated follow-up. • Elastography quantifies liver stiffness. • Contrast-enhanced USG evaluates vascularity without radiation exposure. • Colour Doppler assesses hepatic vessel flow and patency. Computed Tomography • Investigation of choice for vascular anatomical assessment. • It is less expensive and more accessible than MRI. • Excellent for volumetry and surgical feasibility evaluation. • Allows Triple-phase examinations, including: I Arterial Phase I Portal Phase I Delayed Phase (Option C ruled out) • If the lesion is enhanced in the arterial phase, it is hepatocellular carcinoma. Magnetic Resonance Imaging • Best for assessing liver parenchyma and biliary system. • Excellent soft tissue resolution. • Effective in evaluating diffuse liver conditions like steatosis and fibrosis. • Uses gadolinium-based contrast agents (e.g., Gd-DTPA, Gd-DOTA) for T1 enhancement. • Breath-hold 3D T1 weighted sequences allow multiphasic examinations similar to CT. • Hepatobiliary-specific agents target the reticulo-endothelial system (RES) or hepatocytes. • T1-Weighted Images I Normal Liver Parenchyma: Hyperintense compared to muscle, spleen, and kidney. I Pathological Lesions: Typically T1 hypointense due to higher water or cellular density. • T2-Weighted Images I Normal Liver Signal: Hypointense compared to spleen, kidney, and pancreas. I Lesions: Usually hyperintense, aiding in detection. MRI revealed multiple metastatic liver tumours A- T1 MRI, B- T2 MRI Digital Subtraction Angiography • Largely reserved for therapeutic purposes. (Option D ruled out) • Has been superseded by CT and MR angiographies for diagnostics.

questions.question: A 60 y/o jaundiced patient presents with upper abdominal pain. Ultrasound reveals a dilated bile duct, but the cause of obstruction is unclear. What would be the next best non-invasive imaging technique to evaluate this condition?
questions.explanation: particularly effective for diagnosing bile duct obstructions. It also does not rely on the excretion of contrast agents. It is the preferred next step when further non-invasive evaluation is needed after ultrasound, as it can detect stones, strictures, or masses causing the bile duct dilation. MRCP showing common bile duct dilation USG showing double barrel sign Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) (Option B): While ERCP is highly effective for diagnosing and treating bile duct obstructions, it is an invasive procedure. It involves the insertion of an endoscope and contrast injection into the bile ducts, which carries risks like pancreatitis and infection. Though very useful when intervention is required, ERCP is not considered a non-invasive technique, making it less appropriate. ERCP showing dilation of the common bile duct (white arrow) Ultrasound with colour Doppler (Option C): Although a repeat ultrasound with colour Doppler can help distinguish bile ducts from blood vessels by detecting blood flow, it does not provide detailed information on the cause of the dilation. Plain radiography (Option D): Plain X-rays provide minimal information about the biliary system. They may show calcifications, but they cannot assess soft tissues or provide detailed views of the bile ducts

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain. An ultrasound shows echogenic foci with posterior acoustic shadowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: most likely diagnosis in this case, as they typically appear as echogenic foci on ultrasound and produce posterior acoustic shadowing. • This shadowing is caused by the solid nature of the stones, which block the transmission of sound waves. USG Gallbladder polyp (Option A ruled out) • They are typically small masses that protrude into the lumen of the gallbladder. • On ultrasound, they generally appear as smooth, hyperechoic intraluminal lesions without posterior acoustic shadowing, unlike gallstones. USG Gallbladder adenomyomatosis (Option C ruled out) • This is characterised by thickening of the gallbladder wall, often due to cholesterol crystals or small stones in the Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses. • On ultrasound, adenomyomatosis presents with a distinctive comet-tail ring-down artefact (due to reverberation from the cystic spaces), which differentiates it from simple shadowing seen with gallstones. USG Porcelain gallbladder (Option D ruled out) • Porcelain gallbladder refers to a calcified gallbladder wall, which appears as a dense shadowing structure on imaging, typically seen on plain radiographs or CT scans. • It is associated with gallbladder carcinoma. • Ultrasound findings of porcelain GB can resemble emphysematous cholecystitis or large stones, but the condition is characterised by the absence of the double-arc shadow sign seen with gallstones. questions.question: A 45 y/o woman presents with right upper quadrant pain and fever. Ultrasound shows gallbladder wall thickening, gallstones, and pericholecystic fluid. Which of the following findings would most likely suggest chronic cholecystitis rather than acute cholecystitis?
questions.explanation: often shows pericholecystic fluid due to active inflammation. Radiological Differentiation of Acute and Chronic Cholecystitis: Acute Cholecystitis: Ultrasound (US): Gallstones + sonographic Murphy sign (tenderness) (Option A ruled out) Gallbladder wall thickness > 3 mm Gallbladder distension (> 5 cm) Pericholecystic fluid CT Scan: Gallbladder wall thickening Subserosal oedema Gallbladder distension (Option D ruled out) High-density bile (Option C ruled out) Pericholecystic fluid Inflammatory fat stranding Chronic Cholecystitis: Ultrasound (US): Gallbladder wall thickening (without gallstones in many cases) Consider other causes of wall thickening Key Distinguishing Features: Feature Acute Cholecystitis Chronic Cholecystitis Gallstones Present Absent Gallbladder Wall Thickening Pronounced Mild Pericholecystic Fluid/Inflammation Common Rare (Option B) Functional Imaging (CCK-Cholescintigraphy) Not commonly used Impaired contractility (<35% EF) is diagnostic.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about gallstones is correct? imaging.

options.A: Cholesterol stones are typically radiopaque and easily visible on X-rays.
options.B: The Mercedes-Benz sign refers to a star-shaped pattern of gas fissuring in gallstones seen on
options.C: Pigment stones are primarily composed of cholesterol and easily visible on X-ray.
options.D: All gallstones require immediate surgical intervention.

questions.explanation: gallstones seen on imaging. by a triradiate pattern created by gas fissures within the gallstones, which resemble the three-pointed star logo of the Mercedes-Benz automobile. Ultrasound Findings of Gallstones: Appearance: Bright (echogenic) foci with acoustic shadowing. False Negatives: Common due to small stones or poor acoustic access. Differentiation from Polyps: Mobility or acoustic shadowing helps. Double-Arc Shadow Sign: Seen with a gallbladder full of stones, showing two echogenic lines and dense shadowing. Mercedes-Benz Sign in Gallstones: A star-shaped pattern of gas-fissuring within gallstones. It is observed in about 50% of gallstones; often fluid-filled, with some containing nitrogen gas. Indicates potential complications such as cholecystitis, emphasising the need for detailed imaging. Gallstone vs Renal stone: Gallstones Renal Stones Composed of cholesterol, bilirubin, and calcium salts. Comprises various minerals: calcium oxalate, uric acid, struvite, and cystine. Gallstones are better visualised on USG. Renal stones are better seen on CT Cholesterol stones may be hard to see on X-rays but are identifiable via ultrasound due to acoustic shadows. (Option A ruled out) Uric acid stones require non-contrast CT for detection, as they may not show on X-rays. Diagnostic Imaging Techniques Gallstones Renal Stones USG: Commonly used; no ionising radiation. USG: Limited use. CT Scans: Highly sensitive for both stones. CT Scans: Highly sensitive, detects small/radiolucent stones. X-rays: Limited effectiveness. X-rays: Effective for calcium oxalate stones. Pigment stones are primarily composed of cholesterol and easily visible on X-ray (Option C ruled out): Pigment stones are primarily composed of bilirubin and calcium salts, and they might be visible on X-rays. All gallstones require immediate surgical intervention (Option D ruled out): Many gallstones are asymptomatic and do not require immediate surgical intervention unless complications arise.

questions.question: A 45 y/o man from an endemic region presents with abdominal pain. An ultrasound reveals a cyst with multiple septations, resembling a honeycomb. Based on the WHO classification, which of the following stages does this hydatid cyst most likely represent?
questions.explanation: seen in this patient. WHO Classification of Hydatid Cysts (Cystic Echinococcosis): The WHO classification is based on ultrasound findings, helping in diagnosing and managing cystic echinococcosis. WHO Classification Gharbi classification Classification Description Imaging Stage Classification CE1 (Option A ruled out) Unilocular anechoic lesion with a 'double line' sign. Active Type I CE2 (Option B) Cyst with multiple septations, resembling a honeycomb. Active Type III CE3a (Option C ruled out) Unilocular cyst with detached membranes and 'water-lily' sign. Transitional Type II CE3b Cyst with daughter cysts in a solid matrix. Transitional Type III CE4 Heterogeneous echogenicity, no daughter cysts indicating degeneration. Inactive Type IV CE5 (Option D ruled out) Calcified cyst, indicating inactivity. Inactive Type V Imaging: Ultrasound: Primary modality for evaluating hydatid cysts. Identifies key features like floating membranes and daughter cysts. CT and MRI: Used for detecting complications (e.g., cyst rupture, infection).

questions.question: A 65 y/o male presents with severe abdominal pain and elevated liver enzymes. After imaging, he is found to have a suspected bile duct obstruction due to a stone. The physician plans to both visualize and potentially treat the obstruction. Which imaging modality should be chosen?
questions.explanation: scenario because it allows for direct visualization of the bile ducts and allows for simultaneous treatment of obstructions, such as stone removal. Feature Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) Indications • Indications include suspected bile duct calculus, cholestasis, pre-surgical biliary evaluation, biliary leak, unknown aetiology sclerosing cholangitis, and unsuccessful or contraindicated ERCP. • Not typically used for interventions. (Option A ruled out) • It allows for visual assessment of the duodenum and ampulla of Vater. • Allows biopsies, stone extraction, and other Interventional procedures like sphincterotomy, biliary stenting, and biliary stricture dilation. Suitability for Jaundice More Suitable for jaundiced patients Less suitable for jaundiced patients as it is invasive Imaging Type Provides anatomical and functional information Provides dynamic information during contrast introduction Success Rate Substantially replaces PTC and ERCP Success rates of 92%–97% Complication Rates Lower complications; no specified rates Complication rates of 0.9% to 2.3% (severe) Resolution Lower spatial and contrast resolution compared to CT-IVC High spatial resolution for detailed imaging Image Ultrasound (Option C) can help identify biliary obstruction and is a good first-line imaging tool, but it does not provide therapeutic options. Computed Tomography (Option D) can show obstructions and related complications but does not allow for therapeutic interventions. It may be used as a supplementary tool, but ERCP is the preferred option when immediate treatment of a suspected obstruction is necessary.
